text: the competition for great jobs is
fiercer than ever research shows that on
average 250 candidates apply for each
job but only five or six get an
interview and as technology advances AI
will put more jobs at risk you need to
do all you can to stand out and beat the
competition so in this video we'll look
at research-backed methods you've not
heard of to maximize your chances of
success let's get into it tip number one
be a purple cow you're driving down a
country road passing Farm after Farm of
reg brown cows then suddenly you see a
purple one what do you do I bet youd
want to park up and take a closer look
the Purple Cow Isn't So attention
grabbing because it's a little bigger or
a slightly different shade of brown you
notice it because it's unexpected and
totally different from the others the
purple cow is a metaphor that author and
business Guru Seth Goden uses in his
book Purple Cow Goden says that today
businesses can't rely on traditional
marketing and advertising to sell their
products the old ways just don't work
anymore they're not enough every
business uses the same tactics and
techniques so instead to succeed
businesses need to be remarkable they
need to stand out they need to be
different like a purple cow according to
Seth Goden we can apply this idea just
as much to job-seeking recruiters sift
through hundreds or thousands of brown
cows when assessing candidates to give
yourself a shot and set yourself apart
from the 99% think about what will make
someone look twice it could be anything
everyone has something that makes them
difference so lean into who you are
don't be afraid to show hiring managers
your personality you could send a video
CV or make it interactive or use
Graphics or bold colors to make your
qualifications stand out you could even
get creative with your cover letter and
write it as a short story poem or social
media post if that would impress the
company you want to work at another way
to be memorable is to do something most
people don't think about and show how
great your work is instead of just
telling successful job Seekers include
project they've worked on in their
applications or create a website or blog
that recruiters can check out themselves
to really stand out you could even do a
project similar to what you'd be doing
on the job a kind of mock project to
show your initiative creativity and
skills a final option is to list your
unusual and impressive skills or
knowledge maybe you can recite pi to 25
digits perhaps you recently posted a
video on Tik Tok that went viral maybe
you know everything there is to know
about Formula 1 or World of Warcraft
whatever is there could be someone on
the other side of your application who
shares your passions or wants to learn
more and this could be your Edge tip
number two harness the power of weak
ties you've probably heard that when
job-seeking it's not what you know but
who you know while we take this for
granted it wasn't always this way in the
1970s a professor at Stanford conducted
a study on job hunting he took almost
300 men in the US and asked them about
how they got their current positions
surprisingly the researcher found that
what he called weak ties played a much
more important role in helping people
find work than their strong ties strong
ties are the people we know best friends
family and close colleagues in contrast
weak ties are people who are part of
different Social Circles and
professional networks a 2022 follow-up
study of 20 million LinkedIn users over
5 years reached the same conclusion our
weakest connections help us get the jobs
we want and our strongest connections
help the least so how is this why are
people we don't know very well so
powerful for us when job-seeking well
according to weak tie Theory the reason
is that the strong ties are too similar
they might be of a similar age or live
near us and they probably share our
values and interests however weak ties
are often unlike us they might work in a
different industry or city or have
skills we don't this means that weak
ties give us ideas and information we'd
never get from strong ties they connect
us to people and opportunities we
wouldn't usually be exposed to opening
doors and making intros people work
close to tend to have all the same
skills and be pursuing the same roles if
they're struggling to find their dream
jobs it's probably the same reasons you
are they won't have the knowledge and
advice that weak ties have and these are
what'll help you get ahead we should
always be consciously building our
professional and social networks in
person and online throughout school and
at work and when job-seeking we should
think hard about who we know who might
be able to help out out and offer
guidance and reach out to them people
are always more open to helping than we
think and of course the best way to
strengthen ties is always to give back
whenever someone asks for advice from
you tip number three use course careers
you could also stand out and beat the
competition by acquiring the most in
demand skills hiring managers look for
today by trying out course careers they
even include a purple cow automated
resumé generator this gets you in the
front of the line plus they directly
connect you with a network of hiring
managers looking for people with your
new skills Co careers guides you through
the entire process of getting your next
job fast by quickly learning the skills
building a resume or portfolio applying
and interviewing course careers as the
best option to land a fully remote
high-paying job without a degree or
previous experience a recent course
careers graduate just transitioned from
a carpenter to an 80k software
development career within 4 months it
offers many different courses including
technology sales for example where
starting salaries are up to $80,000 or
software development where you can earn
$70,000 to $90,000 as an entrylevel
programmer course careers breaks down
exactly what you need to know to get the
job you want saving you time and the
stress of not knowing where to begin and
trying to figure out everything for
yourself research shows that two-thirds
of people are bored by their work and
almost half wish they had picked a
different career but it's never too late
to make a change if you're willing to
take action if this pequs your interest
and feels like the right step forward
for you check out the link in the
description which will allow you to get
started for free and also get $50 off
the full course tip number four tell a
great story since the beginning of time
humans have been sharing information via
stories it's how we're wired before
writing it was our only way to
communicate and still today our brains
process stories much more easily than
facts and data there's a reason we find
it hard to not keep binging our favorite
shows but get bored looking at
spreadsheets stories make us feel good
storytelling releases chemicals in our
brain like dopamine and oxytocin
associated with pleasure in bonding
making listening to or watching stories
enjoyable a part of the brain called the
lyic system plays a central role in
processing emotions forming memories and
reducing stress stories activate our
lyic system making us more emotionally
invested in them and helping us store
them as long-term memories however we
process data and factual information
more analytically they don't stimulate
the same brain areas instead activating
parts of the brain associated with
logical reasoning and problem solving
despite the power of stories 99% of job
Seekers don't use them they all do the
same thing presenting their experience
and qualifications in a dry factual way
brain expert John Medina says that often
the main reason that one candidate gets
a job over another is that the
successful candidate weaved emotion into
their resume and interview recruiters
aren't as rational as they think they
are they are human too they have
emotions and these emotions will INF
influence what they think of you telling
stories will release Feelgood chemicals
in their brains they'll feel more
positive about you and be more likely to
remember you and they won't know why
telling a story in your application or
interview isn't as hard as it might
sound think about how your skills and
experience fit into a narrative that
makes sense and how the job you're
applying for slots into this story let
your passion for the job come through
and include setbacks and challenges to
make your story more relatable talk
about how you built your skills and
strengths and not just about what they
are and importantly make sure your
stories are genuine madeup stories
always do more harm than good applying
for jobs is tough you need to put
yourself in the best possible position
to stand a chance of succeeding the good
news is that 99% of job Seekers do the
same thing turning in predictable
applications and never thinking outside
the box give these tips a try next time
you're looking to move jobs and let me
